article:
In External Beam Radiotherapy, transverse and longitudinal 'dose measurements'
are taken by a radiation detector in order to characterise the radiation beams
from medical linear accelerators. Typically, an ionisation chamber and water
phantom are used to create these radiation dose profiles. Water is used due to
its tissue equivalence.



Transverse dose measurements are performed in the x (crossplane) or y (inplane)
directions perpendicular to the radiation beam, and at a given depth (z) in the
phantom. These are known dose profiles. Dose measurements taken along the z
direction create radiation dose distribution known as a depth-dose curve.
